newsitem.title: HUNGARY: SHELL SAYS CENTRAL/EAST EUROPE REMAINS PRIORITY.
newsitem.headline: SHELL SAYS CENTRAL/EAST EUROPE REMAINS PRIORITY.

text.p: Shell Oil Products continues to regard central and east Europe as a prime investment target despite profit in Hungary forecast to grow slower than sales, a company official said on Monday.

"The region has half the west European number of cars per 1,000 people, so it has a significant growth potential," Gyorgy Mosonyi, Chairman of Shell's central and east European Companies, told Reuters.
"We aim to be the second largest market player in every country in the region," he said, adding that the first place is usually taken up by national oil companies.

Mosonyi said that Shell Hungary's preliminary figures showed a 650 million forints net profit for 1996 on net sales of 51 billion forints, while for this year the company expects sales to reach 60 billion forints and profit to be between 700 million and 800 million forints.
He said that in the region Shell has the biggest retail chain in Hungary, with 106 petrol stations out of a total 270.
He also said that the company plans to hold on to its 20 percent market share in Hungary despite fierce competition.
"It would be a significant result if we could keep our market share," Mosonyi said.
He also said that Shell plans to expand in all of the region's countries increasing the size of its retail operation "several times" over the next years.
With this year's 4.3 billion forints investment, Shell's total investments in Hungary will reach 17 billion forints, he said.
